DOC.HEAD: Tiny Film Production Company Settles Suit Against Kodak
DOC.TEXT: A small film company that makes videos of the nation's top tourist attractions said Wednesday it had settled a breach-of-contract lawsuit against a division of photography giant Eastman Kodak Co. J.R. Johnson, a co-founder VideoTours, said the company had agreed to drop its lawsuit against Kodak Programs Inc., Kodak's home video division, in exchange for an undisclosed cash settlement. The agreement also calls for Kodak to cease marketing VideoTours' tapes and pay certain royalties due its clients, Johnson said. Kodak spokesman Paul Allen declined to discuss specifics of the settlement, but said it meant the affiliation between the two companies _ one with revenues of $17 billion, the other with sales of $1 million _ was over. Glastonbury-based VideoTours produces videos of top tourist attractions so viewers can ``visit'' the sites without leaving their living rooms. VideoTours filed suit in U.S. District Court in Hartford in October, alleging breach of contract in its distribution deal with Kodak. The lawsuit sought more than $50,000 in damages. VideoTours charged that Kodak failed to help VideoTours market and promote videos already produced and assist in financing additional productions. It also charged that Kodak failed to pay royalties to VideoTours clients, many of whom are non-profit institutions, monitor on-site sales, refill inventories and maintain displays with zoos, aquariums and museums where the tapes are sold. VideoTours, founded in 1986, has produced 13 videos featuring the Monterey Bay Aquarium, Old Sturbridge Village and Mystic Seaport in Connecticut and other sites.
